org.tmotte.pdfrpt

Class FontInfo

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.tmotte.pdfrpt.FontInfo

  • public class FontInfo
extends java.lang.Object
    Contains custom font, font-size, color, and line-spacing information for printing PDF's.

    Note that FontInfo does not contain settings for bold and italics; a separate FontInfo instance must be created for normal, bold and italic versions of a font, which would typically be loaded each from a separate file and managed by the programmer.

    A typical usage scenario would look like this:

       FontInfo fMain=new FontInfo("MyFont.ttf", new FileInputStream("C:\foo.ttf"), 512000)
     .setFontSize(12)
     .adjustLineSpacing(1.2f, 0f);
   FontInfo smaller=new FontInfo(fMain, 8);

    • Field Detail

      • allChars

        public static java.lang.String allChars
        Used for estimating line height. Contains all the characters on a typical English keyboard. The value of allChars can be modified, but it is probably better to make adjustments using adjustLineSpacing().
        See Also:
        getTextLineHeight(), adjustLineSpacing(float, float)

      • setFontSize

      • adjustLineSpacing

        public FontInfo adjustLineSpacing(float top,
                         float bottom)
        Controls the amount of blank space above and below rendered text. When lineSpacingTop and lineSpacingBottom are both 0, text lines will be spaced vertically with the absolute minimum necessary to show the largest glyphs for the specified font size and avoid overlapping with other lines.
        See Also:
        getTextLineHeight()

      • adjustLineSpacingTop

        public FontInfo adjustLineSpacingTop(float top)
        Same as adjustLineSpacing(top, bottom) but only does the top.

      • adjustLineSpacingBottom

        public FontInfo adjustLineSpacingBottom(float bottom)
        Same as adjustLineSpacing(top, bottom) but only does the bottom.

      • setColor

        public FontInfo setColor(int red,
                int green,
                int blue)
        Sets the font color using RGB values. Valid range of values for each parameter is 0-255.

      • setColor

        public FontInfo setColor(java.awt.Color color)
        Sets the font color using Java's standard Color object. This is passed directly to iText's BaseColor object.

      • setColor

        public FontInfo setColor(com.itextpdf.text.BaseColor bc)

      • getMaxAscent

        public float getMaxAscent()
        Gets the maximum ascent (the height above the baseline) for the current font/size. This is recomputed when the BaseFont or font size values are changed.

      • getMaxDescent

        public float getMaxDescent()
        Gets the maximum descent (the height below the baseline) for the current font/size; note that this will be <= 0. This is recomputed when the BaseFont or font size values are changed.

      • alignBaselineTo

        public FontInfo alignBaselineTo(FontInfo largerFont)
        Aligns fonts to a common baseline.

        PText and PTextLines normally position text from the top-left corner instead of the baseline. This makes vertical positioning & alignment easier, but it also means that horizontally aligned instances of different font sizes appear to be "hanging from the ceiling" instead of "planted in the ground".

        This method fixes the problem by increasing FontInfo's adjustLineSpacingTop property to add extra space to smaller FontInfo instances so that they match the baseline position of larger FontInfos. Example:

              FontInfo large=new FontInfo(12), small=new FontInfo(8);
      //This is where we fix the alignment:
      small.alignBaselineTo(large);
      //Aligned horizontally, items will print "correctly" even with different font sizes:
      PGroup group=new PGroup();
      group.addHorizontal(
        new PText(large, "Hello"),
        new PText(small, "World")
      );
        Parameters:
        largerFont - The font to align baselines with. If unsure as to which is "larger" between, say, f1 and f2, do both, i.e. invoke f1.alignBaselineTo(f2) and f2.alignBaselineTo(f1). Extra space will only be added to the smaller font.
        Returns:
        This instance for convenience (not immutable).
        See Also:
        PGroup.addHorizontal(ReportItem), getAdjustLineSpacingTop()

      • getWidth

        public float getWidth(java.lang.String text)
        Obtains the point width of text. This just calls iText's BaseFont.getWidthPoint(text).

      • getWidth

        public float getWidth(char s)
        Same as getWidth(String) but gets the width of a single char.

      • split

        public java.lang.String[] split(java.lang.String str,
                       float width)
        Divides str into two Strings, one that fits inside of width, and the leftover text.
        Returns:
        An array of size 2. The first member will contain the beginning of str up to as much text as will fit inside width; the second member will be null if the entire String fits inside width. The line-splitting algorithm is otherwise basically the same as getFit().
        See Also:
        getFit(String, float)

      • split

        public java.lang.String[] split(float width,
                       java.lang.String str)
        An alternate to split(str, width).

      • getFit

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String> getFit(java.lang.String str,
                                      float width)
        Divides str into a series of Strings, such that each will fit inside width at the current font and size. Also calculates the total height of those "lines" of text. The line-splitting algorithm looks for space characters in str and attempts to split it at those points. If a word is too large to fit on one line, getFit() will break it in the middle and put a hyphen in between; this may not result in strictly "correct" hyphenation, however.

      • getFit

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String> getFit(float width,
                                      java.lang.String s)
        An alternate way to getFit(s, width).

      • loadFont

        public static com.itextpdf.text.pdf.BaseFont loadFont(java.lang.String name,
                                      java.io.InputStream str,
                                      int contentSize)
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Loads a font from an InputStream.
        Parameters:
        name - This MUST have an extension to identify font type; for example, a truetype font could use name "foo.ttf". The rest of the name isn't important, but without the extension, iText cannot identify the font type and will throw mysterious exceptions. This method has only been tested using TrueType fonts.
        contentSize - This must be the size (in bytes) of the data in the InputStream, or a larger value. It may seem silly, but iText demands it.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • loadFont

        public static com.itextpdf.text.pdf.BaseFont loadFont(java.lang.String name,
                                      java.net.URL url)
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Similar to loadFont(String, InputStream, int), but obtains the InputStream and content size from url. Specifically, url.OpenConnection().getContentLength() should provide the size of the content.

        Warning: on Weblogic, resource URL's obtained from the ClassLoader, ServletContext etc. will not provide the content length because everything is being read from a Zip file; this method will throw a RuntimeException in such cases.

        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - If url.getConnection().getContentLength() provides a zero size.
        java.lang.Exception
